p: As early as 1873, adult Culex mosquitoes were observed sucking nectar from the flowers of Ramnus frangula ( Knab 1907), and in 1958, both sexes of Aedes and Culex mosquitoes were observed frequently visiting flowers for nectar ( Downes 1958). However, we also know that nearly all female mosquitoes require a bloodmeal to develop eggs, and in some environments, Ae. aegypti have adapted to seldom feed on sugar, deriving needed energy from blood meals alone ( Scott et al. 1997, Costero et al. 1998a, Naksathit and Scott 1998, Harrington et al. 2001). Mosquitoes can become vectors of disease when they acquire blood from an infected host, but the frequency of biting may be allayed by sugar feeding. Hence, the choices mosquitoes make in obtaining food resources greatly impact pathogen transmission dynamics.
